My Meanness with thy Energy sublime,
Ennoble, and succeed the consecrated Theme.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: The Great Invisible, who, thron'd on high,
Dwells in the Chrystal Palace of the Sky;
Whose Parent word gave all things Birth;
And fram'd the Heav'ns, the Seas and Earth:
VVho, in the vast Expansion's Height,
The radiant Luminaries, slung;
Numberless Worlds of wakeful Light,
Unprop'd in ambient Aether hung:
The fame, whose Pow'r, th' Eternal Base,
Unweary'd, firmly do's sustain
The weight of Nature's Universal Race;
Securing all with an indulgent Reign:
Ev'n He, Superior God, below,
Lost from his Heav'nly State a while,
Of gracious Choice did undergo
Humanity debas'd, and endless Toil:
Pursu'd with agonizing Woe,
Of Wrath awak'd the lashing Scourge he bore;
Pressures of urging Torture unallay'd,
By fiery Vengeance of Almighty Pow'r,
Driv'n home, and fasten'd in his Soul:
Guiltless, for us, a guilty Victim made,
He drank the bitter Dregs, and felt for us the Whole.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: On Mercy's Golden Leaf the Great Design
VVas register'd in Characters Divine:
And there th' Immortal People of the Sky,
Th' unchanging Scroll permitted to their Eye,
Acquainted with th' intended Wonder grew,
And early read it with preventing View.
Below, the Prophets praescious Rage
Foretold th' amazing Birth, and sung in mystick Page.
On this desir'd expected Day
The Patriarch Line fix'd their believing Sight;
Tho' then behind a Length of Time it lay;
Of Years unborn thro' the wide Ocean, they,
To Vision purg'd and Distance of Survey,
Transfer'd their Prospect clear, and hail'd it with delight.
And big and lab'ring with Desire,
All earnestly accomplish'd Grace require;
When, lo, the destin'd, the distinguish'd Hour,
The Flight of intermediate Ages past,
Turn'd up, and smil'd upon the World, at last,
To save from Hell deserv'd, and forfeit Bliss restore.

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: Lull'd in a Calm of Peace our Earth was found,
When on the solemn Ambassy,
Eternal Concord to promulge around,
The Prince and Pledge of Peace descended from on high,
And with his Birth, the Golden Aera, Crown'd.
A Sov'reign rais'd, whose stedfast Throne,
Founded imperishable, unconfin'd,
An Earthly Sceptre greatly do's disown,
And solely claims Dominion of the Mind,
Titles and Train, and Honour cumb'rous Load,
With all the splendid Vanities of Pow'r
Gay Toys, which wretched Man allure,
And puff the silly Creature to be Proud;
Rejected to their vile Admires lie,
ho taste Streams of Praise, and worship Pageantry.
Then, unallarm'd with jealous Fear,
Imperial Caesar, hold thy ample Reign,
Conquests perform, and Trophies rear,
Stretch out unwieldy Empire's Bound,
And thro' the many Nations round,
nlarge Command Supream, and Lordly Rule main∣tain.

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: Born to superior Deeds, to drive
Abusive Error and her various Train;
Unblemish'd Truth and Virtue to revive;
And rescue and assert the Man
From Vassalage of Vice this gracious Monarch came:
Thus builds his Empire, thus aspire to sway,
Reigns Spiritual, and signifies his Way
To Grandeur eminent, and large predicted Fame.
Not introduc'd by Comets hung on high
Flaming dire Omens in the nightly Sky
By Kingdoms ruin'd, and by shaken Thrones,
A Waste of Battle, and translated Crowns.
But War, her blustring Tempest o're,
Slumber'd supine, and hush'd her brazen Roar;
And a fair Sky, all chearful and serene,
Disclos'd, and gave an Auspice to the Scene.

LG.HEAD: VI.
LG.L: Hold on, my Muse, and, if thou can'st sustain
Th' o'rewhelming Thought, and, trembling, see
Lone, unsurrounded with his shining Train
Almighty, prae-existing God;
Humbly, in a mean Abode,
Ent'ring on infant Life, beginning now to be.
Shorn with Eclipse, dishonour'd, spoil'd
Of his effulgent Glory, bare to Sight,
Behold the sacred Child
Disrob'd of that excessive Light
Which, on the Gross of ancient Night
Shot fierce, and made uncomly Darkness yield,
All pale it sicken'd into Day;
And, kindling from his Blaze, their borrow'd Ray,
The sparkling Lamps on high rose in the Starry Way.

LG.HEAD: VII.
LG.L: From vast Infinitude's unfathom'd Space,
The King Dimentionless, assuming Man,
Breaths straitly circumscrib'd in Place,
Diminish'd to the Babe's contracted Span.
Here th' Unoriginal Maker Mind,
Where unsuccessive permanent before,
The standing Species lodg'd their Store;
Which, in a simple View the total Kind
Of Being multiform, survey'd, omniscient unconfin'd.
Abolish'd, wip'd a Blank within,
A Table uninscrib'd he ly's,
And Knowledge, like the Creature, try's
To sculpture on the Void, and print it o're agen.
'Tis swiftly struck; th' Artificer Divine
Prevents the slow Advance of tardy Years:
Refresh'd the same, the primitive Characters
Of Intellect Supream in all their Lustre shine.
In Plenitude th' o'ershadowing Spirit giv'n
Endowments from on high unmeasur'd, bears,
To the First-born and awful Heir of Heav'n.
Low, reverently low
Before thy visible Redeemer bow;
And, with th' admiring Host above,
Adore the Depth profound of unexampl'd Love.

LG.HEAD: VIII.
LG.L: Hark! in the lightsome Chambers of the Sky,
Echo's the Sound of solemn Harmony.
Sweetly the circling Spheres above,
In tuneful Revolutions move:
More sweetly the Cherubic Choir,
And joyful Saints their Voices, raise,
In Hallelujahs of Praise:
And, taught by Master Spirits skill'd,
The breathing Pipe and copious Lyre
Speak Airs Divine, and waken round
Loud Melody in all its Tones fulfill'd;
And the big Organ and the Trump conspire
T' embody and allow their stronger pealing Sound.
The Sons of God their Choral Strain
Thus on Creation's Morn began
Symphonious to th' Omnific Builder's Fame,
While from the unreal vacuous Deep, amain,
Apparent Entity emerging came;
And, working off Confusion's black Array,
The new-born Worlds were publish'd into Day.
A World created, and a World preserv'd,
Occasion'd equal Joy and equally deserv'd.

LG.HEAD: IX.
LG.L: Wing'd from the Presence, to convey
The important News, with speedy Flight,
Down thro' the trackless Skies unmeasur'd Way,
Falls a swift Train of Seraphs bright:
And a fair Globe of running Light:
From the brown Meadows rolls the Night,
Distinguishing the Heav'n, and calls the Shepherds Sight.
In Extasy the humble Swains
Receiv'd the Vision on the Plains;
And as with awful Fear they gaze,
Th' illustrious Host prepare their Lays;
To chiming Instruments around
GLAD TIDINGS, then the Song began,
TO THE SUPREAM ADOR'D ETERNAL PRAISE,
IMMORTAL PEACE, BENEVOLENCE TO MAN.
An Universal Shout the Concert crown'd,
And to the Gates of Paradise return'd the welcom Sound.

LG.HEAD: X.
LG.L: To lab'ring Nature's sickly Frame,
New Life the salutary Message brought;
Establish'd on her Base again:
But Horror and distracting Shame,
Disseiz'd and vanquish'd of his Reign,
Abaddon's swarthy Monarch caught.
He d his Traytor Crew of Hell,
(Vengeance defer'd but gathers Weight,
Strikes deeper, and with more of Fate)
Like hasty Lightning, from on high,
Swept down, precipitately fell,
And clear'd the disincumber'd Sky.
Defeated in th' accurs'd Design;
The new Creation to confound,
To spread their wastful Empire round,
And Man with them in Ruin joyn.
For this, vindictive Wrath Divine
Flam'd out, and visited intense?
Sharp Arrows, drench'd in sacred Ire,
From which they vainly wish Defence
Shot Agonies, immortal Pain
Within 'em, and impetuous Fire
Pursu'd in raging Show'rs amain:
The long-impending Tempest, fully blown,
oke on 'em, and disgorg'd the sultry Deluge down.

LG.HEAD: XI.
LG.L: From meagre Death his lifted Weapon fell;
The sallying Dart arrested was and stay'd;
Which long had stock'd the lonely Waste of Hell,
And, fierce of Prey, enormous Carnage made.
Reform'd to Grace, the horrid Mien,
And griesly Shape no more are seen;
A Friend become of an invet'rate Foe,
Pleasant his Look and mild his Brow,
Balmy the Shafts he sends, and Sov'reign is the Blow.
From Sorrows, and oppressive Cares,
From Sickness and unweildy Years,
The Pains, Indecencies and Scorn
Of Sense obtuse, and Life to Ruin worn
Welcome Deliv'rer, thou Release,
To fadeless Joys and Elegance of Bliss.

LG.HEAD: XII.
LG.L: Infinite King! Who can suffice,
The Secrets of thy Throne, to trace!
Or dare to try, with curious Eyes,
Th' Abyss of thy Mysterious Ways!
Awful, inextricable Maze!
And what an Ocean is thy Grace!
The flaming Ardors of the Sky,
Pure Sons of Morn, a Princely Train,
Magnificent in Majesty,
And lucidly with native Splendors crown'd
Once dignify'd to serve around
Th' immediate Godhead, and sustain
His great Commands, amid the blazing Ray
Of living Light, and strong Caelestial Day:
Revers'd in Form, and from their Station thrown,
Expung'd th' Eternal Roll on high,
Damnation sinks for ever down:
Chain'd in th' unfathom'd Gulf, they lye
Despairing, and unpity'd groan
With Torture's eating Plague, and perfect Misery.

LG.HEAD: XIII.
LG.L: Far otherwise, O Father Judge Supream!
With fallen Man thy Methods were:
To him all Charity; to them
onsuming Wrath unquench'd, and Punishment severe.
What a Distinction hast thou made!
Of lofty Seraphim the radiant Row,
Disclaim'd and lost, no Pardon know,
Out of the Line of Grace, and Mercy's Aid
While Man, a Creature meanly Born of Clay,
A sudden Thing of Yesterday,
Reduc'd in Mind, and sluggishly allay'd
With Body, of abated Soul;
A Spirit tam'd with Sense, and lessen'd in the Whole:
When vilely from his Faith he fell,
And dar'd Allegiance to depose;
Supplanted by th' industrious Wiles of Hell,
Th' Extant of thy Compassion found:
Plenipotent th' imbosom'd Son arose
On his behalf; and, in his Stead,
Who can prescribe his Love, and streighten with a Bound)
The Fury of insulted Law,
Receiv'd, discharging on his Head.
Aghast th' Apostate Spirit saw,
When, to conclude the tainted Race,
Justice, inflam'd, reach'd hasty to the Blow,
The rushing Stroke, in Pity, stay'd;
And Exhibitions of absolving Grace,
The Deity, asswag'd, indulgently bestow.

LG.HEAD: XIV.
LG.L: Bought with a Price and not our own;
His Claim appropriate we are,
Who paid the costly Ransom down
Be Righteous then to Gratitude, nor dare
Profanely to defraud th' Almighty Purchaser.
Unhallow'd Lusts let be expell'd
That impiously usurp'd the Sway within;
Each guilty Passion combatted and quell'd;
And Virgin bleach the Soul renew'd agen
From all discolour'd Soil and Turpitude of Sin.
And Sanctify, with Innocence, the Mind;
Ornate in Virtue's Garb Divine;
A Royal seperated Shrine,
Inscrib'd to Heav'n and from the World refin'd.
To Spirit purifying, when our End
Mature accomplishes for perfect Joys,
Th' immortal Mansions thus we shall ascend;
Assum'd to high Promotions in the Skys;
From whence unnumber'd shining Legions fell;
In Glory with the Hierarchies to dwell,
A Holy Church select, and heal their Vacancys.

LG.HEAD: XV.
LG.L: Increas'd, from Infancy's imperfect Years,
To smiling Youth, and thence absolv'd to Man
One Tenor of the sacred Life appears:
Opprobriously he set, as lowly he began.
A Life still varying, and distinguish'd still,
With Wants, Contempt, and exercising ill.
Rais'd by Adversity, superior grew
The Deity, but heighten'd by the Strife,
So prov'd, and manifest to View,
Self-prop'd, and needless of Relief
It strove thro' all, and foil'd the joyn'd Infernal Crew
Of Grace abundant, on the Crowd
Promiscuous Mercys he bestow'd;
For scurril Taunts, and Blasphemy abhor'd,
He rais'd the Dead the Lame restor'd,
Expell'd possessing Fiends, and wasting Sickness cur'd.
Persisting in the righteous Ways of Good,
The narrow Path unerringly he trod.
Constant, and truly regular,
He roll'd along his destin'd Sphere,
And greatly measur'd his compleated Year,
(If Things so Great we may compare with Small)
Drives steadily his Chariot on;
Sweeping around the glitt'ring Belt on high
His chearful Beams he freely throws on all
While climbing Fogs and Vapours vainly try
To blunt his Golden Rays, and cloud the Aetherial Ball.

LG.HEAD: XVI.
LG.L: But, conscious of abated Fire, forbear,
My weary'd Muse, t' attempt the rest,
They feeble Force exceeding far,
And curb thy self in thy ungovern'd Haste.
A Chain of Virtues so divinely bright,
Able t' endure the proving Test
Proportion'd, perfect, of Immortal Height,
Cannot be worthily exprest.
Besides the Wonders of his Death behind:
When, lab'ring on the Cross, his earnest Pray'rs
(Made prevalent by Blood and Tears)
Were for his Murders design'd:
n Blessings then his anguish'd Soul he breath'd,
And sure Salvation's Gift to Rebel Man bequeath'd.
The Glories, also, thou must leave untrac'd,
When, breaking from the solitary Tomb, he rose,
August with purchas'd Honours grac'd,
In Triumph o're his vanquish'd Foes.
The Taper of his Life, put out before,
Reviv'd self-kindl'd by Essential Pow'r.
Thro' purple Clouds serenely as he rode,
Applauding Angels, spread on high,
With Songs of Joy receiv'd the Victor God:
A Blaze of Suns the frequent Host appear'd;
And loudly, in th' expanded Sky,
The vollying Voice of hailing Praise was heard,
Such Crowds, and such a pompous Train
Agen shall fill that spacious Plain,
When his Tribunal high
Erected in the Sky,
Shall, by the Trumpet's Clangor wake
The sleepy Dead and their long Slumber break;
And summon all the World to come
And meet their Just and Everlasting Doom.
WEary of Life, with Restless Thoughts opprest,
Fatigu'd with Worldly Care, and quite deprest
With dire Despair, reflecting on this State
Of ceaseless Woe, that on Us Mortals wait,
My melancholy Muse with Grief bemoans
The several Scenes of Life, which from the Womb
Till (worn with Pains and Age) to Death we come.
VVith dolorous Cries into the World we come,
sure Presage that it is Mankind's Doom,
During this Mortal State, to undergo
ryals severe, and never-ceasing Woe.
n Infancy by Tears and Cries we prove
Th' indulgent Patience of our Parent's Love:
n Childhood we pursue, void of all Fear,
uch Things as certain Ruin doth declare,
not prevented by Paternal Care:
Of Toys and Trifles fond, which when acquir'd,
Soon slighted are, tho' with such hast desir'd:
VVith Novelties most pleas'd; sometimes a Song
Shall Mirth create, but ne'er contented long:
Part of our Time in Laughter, part in Tears
Is spent, 'till Reason dissipates our Fears;
Then we to School are sent, where we submit
to Discipline severe, to make us fit
For Trade and Business; but the more polite,
With never-ceasing Diligence and Might,
Laborious strive at Learning's chiefest Height.
Studious and Thoughtful, they neglect their Food,
Ruin their Health, t' attain a fancied Good;
VVith sleepless Nights their wretched selves they ve
VVith anxious Studies they their Days perplex,
Till dire consuming Pains in them take Place,
Foretold by meagre Symptoms in the Face.
Sometimes, 'tis true, a Constitution bears,
And Health enervate overcomes these Cares;
Yet when with Indefatigable Pains.
Of Mind and Body he his End has gain'd,
His Parts shall slighted be, his Works despis'd,
His Person scorn'd; the reason is, he's VVise:
'Tis Blockheads, Fools, and Knaves the Darlings be
Of this degenerate VVorld, we daily see:
Merit and Virtue, Honesty and Grace,
Can hardly, very hardly find a Place.
Not so in Ancient Times, the more our Shame,
VVhen Men by MERIT only got their Fame;
Then did untainted Valour Heroes make,
And Virtue loved was for Virtue sake:
Then Old Fabricius, fam'd for Honesty,
(VVith all her Gold) could not Rich Sparta buy
His Country to betray: (O golden Days!
Altho' but light with Reason's glimm'ring Rays)
VVhereas, in this our Time, for cursed Gold
Men sell their Country, nay, their very Soul.
In blooming Youth (that dang'rous time) we prove
That wretched, anxious, restless Passion, Love:
With Heart of Blood inspir'd, and fatal Gust,
We hurried are into impetuous Lust;
Enticed with 'luring Words, deluding Smiles,
Attractive Looks, and all the other Wiles
Wherewith the Sex abounds, who always have
Jointly endeavour'd to make Man their Slave;
Who, thoughtless of Deceit, ne'er strives to shun
Their Syren Falshood, but to Ruin run;
Fir'd with Borrow'd Charms and Airy Dress,
On fancid Beauty fixes Happiness.
Being sincere themselves, they ne'er mistrust
Their Falshood and Deceit, but to 'em trust,
Thinking their Words and Actions do declare
Unfeigned Truths, and Beauties real are;
When all is but Decoy, t'entice Men in
And make 'em guilty of Enormous Sin:
Their Words are Lyes, their Actions are Deceit,
Their Face is Paint, their Heir is Counterfeit;
That when the nauseous Pleasure is enjoy'd,
The Faculties are with possession cloy'd;
Then, then our Mind's perplex'd with Folly past,
With Guilt and gloomy Sorrows overcast,
Our Body's languishing with wracking Pain,
A minute's Ease or Respite can't obtain.
By Conscience gnaw'd, and void of all Relief,
We suffer most intolerable Grief,
Till by sincere Repentance we appease
nded Heaven, who only can us ease:
ometimes where Truth and Honour have inclin'd
o tread in Virtuous Paths, a Man may find
rue Satisfaction and Content of Mind.
There be among the Sex that Virtue use:
ut we with Reason, not with Lust, must chuse:
Such lovely Delia is by all confest,
With all Perfections, every Virtue blest;
Seraphick Charms adorn her blooming Face,
Her Modesty not Envy's self can raze;
Agreeable in Humour, always mild
And easie, free from all Deceit and Guile;
With Wit and Sence endow'd beyond compare,
Her Faultless Actions every day declare:
Happy, thrice happy, he whose blessed Fate
Obtains this Charmer in a Marriage-state.
Tho' Fortune be so kind to chuse a Maid
With all those Virtues which blest Delia had,
Yet still, before the Nymph you can obtain,
You must endure Variety of Pain,
With wracking Disappointments, constant Care,
Attended with the Passions, Hope and Fear.
Sometimes you must expect to be receiv'd
With seeming Detestation, which will grieve
Your very Heart and Soul; anon with Smiles
And pleasing Raptures she your Mind beguiles:
One Hour in Exstasie, the next Despair,
This fill'd with Transport, that with tearing Hair;
'Till with assiduous Care, and due Respect,
And low Submission, which they all expect,
Her Coyness you o'ercome, with loving Eyes
She views your Passion, and rewards your Cries:
Her Pity doth Indifference destroy,
In lieu of which succeeds Exstatick Joy,
With melting Kisses; chaste Embraces prove
Th'Angelic Pleasures of a Mutual Love.
O blissful state! if we could but retain
These Joys, which vanish like a Golden Dream!
For then a Paret's or a Guardian's Leave
Must be acquir'd, who will before he give
His Approbation, strictly too request
A Sum proportion'd to what you possess;
Which if not to be had, he'll strait declare
Your Choice is mean, you must your Suit forbear:
Prayers most fervent he will never mind,
And he to Wit or Virtue's always blind.
Thus Sacred Love depends upon a Dower,
And must submit to cursed Money's Power:
Th' Idea from your Mind you must efface,
Or Ruin with the lovely Nymph embrace.
Again; When Parents, Friends, and all conspire
To crown your Joys and satisfie Desire,
ome slighted Rival, fill'd with Love and Rage,
With fatal Lines your Honour doth engage▪
Who desperate grown, and covetous o Death,
our Life assaults for to appease his Wrath.
Thus were I all the Ills of Love to tell,
This little Tract would to a Volume swell;
But this shall now suffice, while I pursue
A Theme which to my Muse is wholly new,
A Secret that's to Younger Years unknown,
Taught by Experience, when to it we come.
Assist me, Mighty Jove, while I relate
The Jarring Hours that fill the Marriage-state:
Thou, tho' Superiors to Human Kind,
And to a Goddess married, ne'er could'st find
ither Content or Pleasure in the state,
Which is to Gods and Men Unfortunate.
Marriage is like a Trap for Wasps and Flyes,
uscious at top, at bottom Poyson lies:
eluded with its outward gaudy Dress,
The Serpent in our Bosom we embrace,
Till cherished too long, too late the Sting
We feel, infecting all our Parts within:
is a slavish Freedom, bitter Sweet,
Where Jarrs and Contradictions always meet;
The dire Effects of which we daily see:
Love may make Friends, but Marriage Enemy.
Poor miserable Man! made to controul
The frailer Sex born with a nobler Soul,
Blinded by Passion, meekly doth submit
The Power his Maker did to him commit
To Silly Woman, falacious Smile,
And wheedling Art his Senses doth beguile,
'Till drawn into the Noose, too late doth find
Her (who before was lowly, meek, and kind)
Proud as a Fiend, and louder than the Wind)
His Peaceful Hours are now for ever gone,
And Swarms of Anixious Cares come trouling on:
Perhaps a Spurious Off-spring on him creep,
Which, whether his or not, he's forc'd to keep:
On these a constant Care and Change attend,
For upon him alone they do depend:
With Pious Education fill their Mind,
If Pleasure in 'em you expect to find.
With Sums immense your Quiet you must buy,
For what she wants you must not once deny,
Whether it be for Cloaths, or treating Friends,
Abroad or Home, for how she please she spends
Your Wealth; nor must you know, but still prepare
Supplys sufficient, 'till you ruin'd are.
But if you do a large Estate command,
Enough to satisfie her large Demand,
Yet when in am'rous Play and gloating Eye
You see the Wanton with her Stallion lye,
You curse the fatal Hour you saw her Face,
Yet must with Patience bear the vile Disgrace:
For, tho' the Wise the damning Shame procures,
Yet (if divulg'd) the Husband Scorn endures.
But if a Man should be so fortunate
To chuse a Wife whose Virtues are innate,
Whose modest pious Thoughts ne'er tainted were,
But, like an Angel's, innocent and clear,
And such I hope there is, (Oh! may my Fate
Bless me with such, if e'er I change my state)
Yet still numerous Disquiets must attend,
And so towards this World your Thoughts you'd bend▪
Your Cares for your Posterity ne'er wou'd cease,
But with laborious Toil you'd marr your Ease.
Children unfortunate our Grief demands,
Or disobedient to our just Commands:
Servants Negligence doth highly aggravate;
Uneasie still we are in every State;
Felicity on Earth we can't obtain,
Our greatest Pleasures blended are with Pain;
Diseases, Pains, and Troubles numberless
Attend Mankind, and with Old-age encrease;
Covetous of Money, with perplexing Cares
And restless Toil they spend their wretched Years:
Dissatisfied with Life, fearful to Die,
Tho' miserable, dread ETERNITY:
Morose and peevish, greedy still to live,
Tho' neither Day nor Night Content can give:
Envious of Joys which they want Sense to taste,
The thoughts but irksom are of those that's past;
With grudging Eyes and sullen Face they view
Their former Pleasures, which they can't renew:
Our brisk Desires they strive for to destroy,
Forgetting what they did in Youth enjoy:
Maliciously the Follies they display
Of Joys belonging to the Young and Gay.
f guilty of Excess in greener Years,
We in declining Age th' Effect must bear;
Drunkenness, that filthy Vice, which hath debas'd
The Soul of Man, and made him worse than Beast,
That darling Sin of Our Unhappy Land,
Wasteth the Body and the Wealth of Man;
alsie and Dropsie, Gout and Fevers, these,
With more, consume the Body by degrees;
Tormenting Anguish, and corroding Pain,
With griping VVant, the just Efects we gain.
'Tis not this Vice alone, but all the rest,
As VVhoring, Gaming, and Voluptuousness,
Of whatsoever kind, that's to excess.
You by Experience will, when Strength's declin'd,
Th' aforesaid Evils sad Attendance find;
Wherefore, if any Peace of Mind you'd have,
Or would with comfort live, earnestly crave
Divine Assistance, to restrain betimes
Depraved Nature, which to Vice inclines:
Let VVatchfulness and Care thy Youth attend,
And in assiduous Prayer thy Leisure spend;
With daily Supplications beg an Heart
That's new, upright, and pure in ev'ry part;
Assistance great thou want'st, Vice out to drive,
And with a mighty Opposition must thou strive▪
The World's deluding Baits, Honour and Fame,
And Pleasures great to heedless Youth lay claim;
Satan's Enticements too, whose Devilish Wiles
With glitt'ring Joys our easie Hearts beguiles.
Added to these Beauty's bewitching Fires,
Which youthful Hearts enflame with bad Desires:
To resist these grand Temptations, thou wilt find
Abilities thou want'st, thy Will to bind;
O, therefore beg it of the Powers Divine:
With Fervency and Zeal thy self apply,
And they will not thy humble Suit deny:
Thus being assisted with a Heavenly Aid,
Thy Soul serene of nought will be afraid,
But, blest with Peace, with Thoughts sublime will raise▪
Triumphant Songs to her Creator's Praise;
And when at last to drooping Age we come,
And Death, which soon or late must be our Doom,
We can with Pleasure on our Life reflect,
And with Transporting Joy our Change expect.
But, O the Horrours of the Guilty Soul,
Whom no Advice nor Reason cou'd controul,
Who all his Days in Wickedness hath spent,
In Brutal Lust indulging every Sense!
When to Old-age he cometh, wrack'd with Pain,
(Th' Effects of Youth's Excess he can't obtain
A moments Rest or Peace, but (conscious) stand
Dreading the weight of the Almighty's Hand;
With Guilt appal'd, trembling, and in a maze,
Remorsless Conscience staring in his Face;
Contrite and sorrowful, tho' now too late
He gladly would himself annihilate,
But that can't be obtain'd, live still he must,
To be with Pain and Endless Torments curst,
In Fire unquenchable blaspheming lie,
Scorching in Flames to all Eternity.
This is the Just Reward MAN must expect,
f he his Duty to his GOD neglect.
Then happy he whose Days and Hours have been
Holy and pure, free from Enormous Sin:
True Piety alone Content can give,
To which no other way we can arrive;
For Earthly Pleasures transient are and vain,
Empty and void, like to an airy Dream;
O, therefore fix your Mind on Joys above,
And let thy Heart no Impious Thought approve,
o shall your Hours in unmolested Ease
Glide smoothly on, blest with an Inward Peace:
And when at last the Icy Hand of Death
hall grasp our brittle Life, and stop our Breath,
Our expanded Souls enlarg'd, shall upwards move,
Carried by Angels to the Joys above,
With Bliss Extatick, fill'd with Glorious Rays,
There for to sing (JEHOVAH's) Endless Praise.
