DIV1.HEAD: THE COMMONER, A POEM.
DIV1.Q: Omnia quae fulgent non auri nomen haberent.
DIV1.P: LONDON▪ Printed and Sold by H. Hills, in Black-fryars, near the Water-side. 1710.

DIV1.HEAD: TO ALL COMMONERS Who live like Gentlemen.
DIV1.P:
THESE Lines are not intended to expose all Commoners in general, but only such as pretend to enter so, when in Truth they can scarce live handsomely Servitours; (I could give many Instances of this nature, but Names wou'd be offen∣sive) and yet wou'd willingly impose on the World, Quòd Craso ditiores fuerint cùm Io reversà pauperiores appareant. These are the Men hinted at, These are the Men to be exposed, which to do nicely is a Task that far transcends my Genius, but I hope some abler Pen will finish what I have im∣perfectly begun. So vain are these Men to think that the Tuffs alone make a Gentle∣man, that they will huff and bully those that are by much their Betters, when per∣haps
they han't one Farthing in their Pock∣ets to keep the Devil out; but being Com∣moners (altho' scandalous) they endeavour to ride Paramount, and foolishly indulge themselves in a stupid Fondness of being counted Genteel, when perhaps but last Year they followed the Plough, or else which is worse, served their Brother Hogs. So wish∣ing that every one would learn to know him∣self and act according, I subscribe my self,

LG.L: WHEN Titan with his splendid Rays had blest
The drooping Earth, with Winter's Cold opprest,
And grateful Ceres did begin to smile
On Peasants that had grumbl'd a long while,
Then 'twas that a poor Bumpkin who had been
Some Lord's Foot-Page, or else some Farmer's Hind,
Began to rent a Farm ten Pounds per Year,
And liv'd as great as Lords at Westminster,
As he thought: He thriv'd, and strait begun
To chuse a Mate, by whom he got a Son.
Of Nursing of this Son I shall not treat,
Who lay in Blankets oft for want of Sheet.
Altho' thus hardy bred, the Boy yet thriv'd,
And to six Years of Age at length arriv'd,
And then to School the Bumpkins their Son sent,
(The following Lines shall shew for what Intent,)
As by the Fire Old John and Joan were sate,
And Dame pull'd up her Coats (as wont) to heat—
The Sparks of Fire did her Black Nest annoy,
And then she thought on the fled Bird, her Boy.
And thus spoke: John, what shall we do, (says she)
With our Young Darling Son, my Boy Tommy?
Labor'ous Tasks we've under gone with Sweat
To get our Bread, and very often wet
Have been as high as fork'd, and all we can
Endeavour'd of Tom t' make a Gentleman.
What mean you by a Gentleman? ask'd he,
And said, our Tom shall go to plough with me.
Vor he's sturdy, lusty, sprack, and bold,
Stout, surly, strong, and can the Plough Tail hold.
Knows very well, how with an Hey or Hoe
To make the Horses slow'r, or faster goe:
This Work, I think, 'tis best to put him to.
Therefore let's breed him to this Business, Wife;
Vor 'tis an Healthy and Gold-getting Life.
At this she storm'd and raving swore aloud,
That her Son should not work, do what he would.
At last to put a stop to further Strife,
Old John was forc'd to yield, to please his Wife.
The Boy to School must go for six Years more;
Which being expir'd, he knew as much before
As now he did almost: Excepting this,
To grope a Maid, or give a stabb'ring Kiss.
But when the Boy was grown to full Fifteen,
A second Conf'rence was begun between
The careful Parents; what they had best do
With this their Son: And what to put him to.
The Father said he should his Living get
By lopping Beards: The Old Dame in a Pet
Cries no— no, John, he shall a Parson be,
We'll send him to the University.
For Scholarship he is most Excellent,
Can read the Bible and the Testament.
Therefore to Oxon let us send him quick,
Who knows but he may get a Bishoprick.
But yet suppose he can't attain that Station,
But hath the poorest Parish in the Nation,
That doth not yield him past ten Pounds a Year,
He then may preach to Day, the next sell Beer.
And after Evening Zarmon, ('tis no sin)
May play on Fiddle to call Custom in.
An hot Dispute there was: Which to decide,
I'll to his Master gwo, the Old Man cry'd,
That I mayn't loose my Work, I'll walk anon
To zee the Master when the Boys are gwon.
Thus spoke: In hast out sets the good Old Man,
With flopping Hat and Hazell Stick in hand.
But when within the Sight of t' House he came,
Cock't was his Hat, and cleans'd his Hazell Cane.
At Door he knocks: Out came the Master strait,
And to the Clown gave Entrance at the Gate.
So soon as seen, three Rev'rend Bows were gave,
As Papists do when they adore the Grave
Of some renown'd Saint, who in former Days
For Conquest over Sin did wear the Bays.
When Compliments were past, thus spoke the Boar,
'Zur I am come to be advis'd, bevore
'That I my lurned Zon do from School take,
'Wore I had best of him a Priest to make.
'Vor he have cost me many Pounds I'm zure,
'The which to raise much Labour I endure.
'But yet I will not grudge my pains, if he
'But by his Lurning may a Bishup be.
'I have a mind to zend him to Oxvord,
'That he hereafter may live like a Lord.
To which the Master smiling, Answer made,
It will be better for him than a Trade.
Some Rules I will, good Farmer, your Son give,
That he as cheap as if at Home may live.
A Servitour; you may maintain him cheap
For three or four Shillings I'm sure a Week.
'A Zarvitor! Zur I should be asham'd
'That zuch a thing should be hereafter nam'd.
'For Vorty Pounds a Year I have been told
'A Mon might live, and keep zum store of Gold
'To zerve Occas'on if he should be ill,
'Zo much I will afford with a free Will.
He may live on't, if he'll but careful be,
But somewhat shabby (as you'll quickly see.)
'He must live close (quoth he) as I have done,
'Or else I'm zure he must again come Home.
And thus advis'd, he with three formal Scrapes
Draws back; and of the Master his leave takes.
Full fraught with News he hurries Home in hast,
Relates to Joan what had betwixt them past.
At this the Dame was pleased wondrous well,
And said, That she next Market-Day would zell
Eggs, Cheese and Butter, and would also buy
Zom things to fit her Zon for Varsity.
The Day is come: With speed out sets the Dame,
(And her Horse prov'd to be in one Foot lame)
But by good Chance she to the Market came.
Willing she was to sell, but yet sold dear,
Consid'ring the great Charges of the Year.
At last she sold: And with the Money bought
Some rugged Freze to make her Son a Coat.
The Taylor's sent for, and must come with speed,
Because it is a thing of Urgent Need.
The Boy is measur'd, and strict Charge is given
To make it large, to turn upon occasion.
The old Plough Mare that work't her self most blind,
now put up to fat against the time
That they for Oxford do their Journey take,
That there she may some gallant Figure make.
ow all things are got ready, and the Boy
overwhelm'd in Extasie of Joy.
Tom (says the Father) get your Boots wel greas'd,
And all things vit, or else I shan't be pleas'd.
Vor Mounday Morn, I do intend to gwo
To zee if I do like Oxvord or nwo.
The Boy does all he can, and ready gets
the appointed time; if dry, if wet,
They must set out, for sure they cannot spare
Their precious time to wait for Weather fair▪
other and Son begin to weep amain,
aing they should not see each one again.
To him a piece of good Plumb-Cake she slides,
And says 'twill serve to eat as you do ride.
Now Father mounts his old Dun cripled Beast,
The Son an Ass nineteen Years old at least.
Longing to see dear Alma Mater's Face,
With rusty Spur pricks Horse to mend his pace.
But by hard Riding having Leather lost,
Tom thought he had rid with the Devil Post;
Curs'd all the Sciences, and bid Hell take
And spoil all Learning for his poor Bum's sake.
Fortune was kind, and on them still did smile,
'Till they to Oxford came within a Mile:
Where on a sudden a Gowns-Man they saw,
Who on their Spirits struck a dreadful Awe.
'What's that? Cries Tom, alass, I greatly fear
'The Place that's Bedlam call'd is seated here.
'For zure that Man is mad, or he would ne'er
'A square Clout instead of a Beaver wear.
But when they came a little further in,
They saw some Deans that had been circuiting.
'They'r mad indeed (says the Old Man) alack!
'Here come some Men with Red Rags at their Back.
To Inn they come: Calls for a private Room,
And the Old Man reads Tom his Fatal Doom.
'Now Zon (quoth he) mark and mind what I zay,
'And study hard as well at Night as Day.
'Take care of Evil Company, my Zon,
'And do not into vicious Courses run.
'Abstain from Drink, Rakes Company decline,
'And be at Home before the Clock strikes Nine.
Thus having said: He whistled for the Host,
And order'd him to bring up a large Toast,
Sugar and Ale, Nutmeg and Spice, that he
And Tom together might sup lovingly.
So having ended Supper, went to bed,
After they had some mumbling Prayers said.
But Toast lying heavy on the Maw, Tom lay
Cursing the Night and wishing for the Day.
No sooner had the watchful Cock declar'd,
That Sol's bright Chariot in the East appear'd;
But up he gets, and nicely put on's Cloaths,
Brushing his Hat and Rowling up his Hose:
Hose: So I call them, for they were home-spun,
One part Black Wool inter-wove with White Thrum.
His Wastcoat, Coat and Breeches were of Freze,
Which dangled down a Foot below his Knees.
His Hair was thin, short and Canonical,
Like that of Friars, shap'd by Edge of Bowl:
Naked on top, (by which Emblem they show
That Aetna cold above, is hot below,
And that they as much as brisk young Men can do.
Thus being dress'd, they walkt abroad to see
The Buildings of the University.
They thought the Schools a Church, so entred in
To see the Rareties that were therein:
Dirty their Shoes, walking they did refrain,
Pull'd off their Hats, and so march'd out again.
Passing along, they did with Joy repair
To see that stately Pile, the Theatre:
Where they but little saw, as they thought rare,
Except some Benches, and an old work'd Chair.
To Physick-Garden then they bend their Course▪
But the Old Man was forc'd to ride on's Horse;
For Stockings stiff and dirty by the Sweat
Had miserably gall'd his stinking Feet.
But when they at the Garden Door arriv'd,
Shafer dismounting Steed, on each hand spy'd
Two Men in Green of a prodigious Size,
With Mouths from Ear to Ear and Sawcer Eyes.
To them these Men of Yew-Tree did appear,
Gigantes fierce, which made them run for fear.
Rambling on farther still, at last they come
Unto the Place, where hangs Ill-natur'd TOM,
Whose dreadful Sound calls Scholars Home at Nine,
Tho' in the midst of Jollity and Wine.
And makes them hurry Home in hast; tho' they
Are willing to sit up till break of Day.
No sooner had Old Tag the Bell perceiv'd,
But he (well read in Scripture) strait believ'd
That 'twas the Son of great God BELL and said,
That to his Father Kings great Homage paid.
Therefore with Hat in hand, he and his Son
Bow'd low: The Hammer presently struck One:
Whose Stroak Tom feeling, made a dismal Noise,
And told it One a Clock by his hoarse Voice.
At this Old Waggum frightned, would not stay,
But mounting Shagg, rode hastily away.
They came to Inn, and whilst they din'd, did tell
The Dangers manifold that them befel.
And having din'd, a second Walk they went,
And to the Tutor's Chamber their Course bent.
Where being come, they thrice knockt at the Door:
Out came the Rev'rend Tutor: But before
He came in sight, their Hats were held in hand,
And trembling stood as tho' on Holy Land.
With thrice three Bows our Senior Peasant said,
'Zur, I have brought my Zon that you might aid
'Him in zome things: I will of him Care take,
And be his Friend for his old Master's sake,
The worthy Tutor said: And then begun
To ask some Quest'ons of the Farmer's Son.
To every Word the Youngster spoke, a Nod
Was gave, as tho' he fear'd the Lash of Rod.
'What Gown do you design that he shall wear?
'Alas, good Zur, he is a Commoner.
The Gown's put on; the Boy himself can't know
(No Wonder) for he looks like some Scare-Crow.
Of all their other Acts I shall not speak,
Because, I'm sure, they would take up a Week.
Now 'tis high time for Gaffa to go Home,
nd leave behind him his Beloved Son.
ll leave him on his Journey to Fate's Care,
nd see what do become of his young Heir.
he Tyro struts and vaunts, and shakes his Gown,
hinking himself the finest in the Town.
ulls out his Money, hectors all the rest
f the same Gown, and counts himself the best.
one dares to speak without his Hat in hand,
nd ev'ry one must run at his Command.
t now observe what Courses he doth take:
hen one Year's past, (and if I don't mistake)
The Scene is alter'd much; for now you'll find
His Pockets empty, but still full his Mind.
Shoes, Caps and Shirts and taken upon Tick,
And ten to one but that he shows a Trick.
Or if not so: He can't from Chamber come,
For fear of that pestiferous thing, a Dun.
If one knocks at the Door, (altho' well known)
'Tis hard to get Admittance: lest that one
Should come along with him, whose Aspect would
Him scare, and stop the circulating Blood.
Thus miserable lives the Vaunting Beau,
And dares not, but his Head like Owls, to show.
All this is very true, I do protest,

L.HI: Cum multis aliis quae nunc perscribere longum est.
